intro: Valeriana caparaoensis, commonly known as the Caparaó valerian, is a flowering plant native to the Atlantic Forest of Brazil. It belongs to the Caprifoliaceae family and is characterized by its aromatic, often hairy leaves and clusters of small, white to pinkish flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments, such as undergrowth in humid forests. Its rhizomes and roots are used in traditional medicine for their sedative and calming properties. Valeriana caparaoensis is considered a rare and endangered species due to habitat loss and limited distribution.
